Carl Cowl Papers TAM 184
3 Linear Feet (3 boxes)
circa 1960-1992
Conditions Governing Access
Materials are open without restrictions.
Immediate Source of Acquisition
Materials found in repository, but were likely donated by Carl Cowl circa 1993. The accession number associated with this gift is 1980.016.
Historical/Biographical Note
Carl Cowl (1900-1997) grew up in Duluth, Minnesota and joined the Industrial Workers of the World as a teenager. In 1919 he became a founding member of the Young Communist League and soon thereafter joined the Communist Party, USA. Cowl was expelled from the Communist Party in 1928 as a member of the Left Opposition. He was active in the 1934 Teamster strike in Minneapolis, and the next year split from the Trotskyists. In the early 1960s Cowl attended Brooklyn College and became a musicologist. Cowl also worked as a literary agent.
Preferred Citation
Identification of item, date; Carl Cowl Papers; TAM 184; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.
Scope and Content Note
This collection primarily contains political papers, including articles, subject files, clippings and correspondence. Subjects include Marxism, the Left Opposition and the Marxist Educational Collective.
Conditions Governing Use
Copyright (and related rights to publicity and privacy) to materials in this collection created by Carl Cowl was not transferred to New York University. Permission to use materials must be secured from the copyright holder.
